notes: This file is designed to be parsed twice: (1) LLM enrichment (edit/extend explanation/usage/examples/media), then (2) DB import.
Points are intentionally granular enough for credit assignment (atomic uses where practical).
Sections are aligned to functional discourse goals so on-device tutoring can target the right grammar/vocab for the conversation.
functional_discourse_goals: Introduce self and others (basic personal info)
Describe routine and habits with more detail
Narrate a simple past event sequence (what happened, when, where)
Talk about time, dates, schedules, and durations
Express needs, ability, obligation, and preference

sections.title: A2
sections.description: Russian A2 grammar pack organized by communicative function and form.

sections.title: Functional discourse goals
sections.description: What the learner should be able to do at A2 (CEFR-aligned).

sections.title: Sentence foundations
sections.description: Word order, predicates, agreement, punctuation basics for A2.

sections.title: Questions
sections.description: Expanded question forms and indirect questions.

sections.title: Negation
sections.description: Double negation, negative pronouns/adverbs, and contrast.

sections.title: Cases (expanded)
sections.description: A2 expansion of case functions and key prepositions.

sections.title: Genitive
sections.description: Genitive uses and high-frequency prepositions.

sections.title: Dative
sections.description: Indirect objects and core dative constructions.

sections.title: Instrumental
sections.description: Instrumental predicates, tools, accompaniment, and key prepositions.

sections.title: Prepositional
sections.description: Location and 'about' topics; plural and locative exceptions.

sections.title: Accusative
sections.description: Duration, selected verbs, plural animacy, and key prepositions.

sections.title: Pronouns and determiners
sections.description: Full-case pronoun systems; reflexive, possessive, demonstrative, indefinite.

sections.title: Adjectives and adverbs
sections.description: Declension patterns, comparatives/superlatives, and adverb formation.

sections.title: Numerals and time
sections.description: Expanded numerals and time/date expressions.

sections.title: Verbs and aspect
sections.description: Aspect selection, future forms, past patterns.

sections.title: Reflexive and -ся meanings
sections.description: Daily-action reflexives and -ся passive-like uses.

sections.title: Modality and conditionality
sections.description: Polite requests, obligations, hypotheticals, purpose clauses.

sections.title: Motion verbs with prefixes
sections.description: Prefix meanings, key perfective/imperfective motion pairs.

sections.title: Complex sentences
sections.description: что-clauses, который, если, когда; reported questions.

sections.title: Impersonal and states
sections.description: Weather/time, dative experiencer states, wants/necessity patterns.

grammar_points.title: Word order variation for focus (fronting object, time adverbial, contrast with а)
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Word order variation for focus (fronting object, time adverbial, contrast with а).

This point supports A2 communication by adding a specific structure you can practice directly.

**How to use it:** Learn it as a pattern first, then expand with new vocabulary.

**Watch for:** case agreement, verb endings, and word order in questions/negation.

examples.translation_text: Today I read/am reading a book.
The book, I read in the evening.
I'm a student, and he's a teacher.

grammar_points.title: Predicate noun in instrumental with быть (past and future)
grammar_points.summary: Predicate noun in instrumental with быть
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Predicate noun in instrumental with быть (past and future).

This point supports A2 communication by adding a specific structure you can practice directly.

**How to use it:** Learn it as a pattern first, then expand with new vocabulary.

**Watch for:** case agreement, verb endings, and word order in questions/negation.
grammar_points.usage_notes: With professions/roles in past/future, instrumental is common: **был студентом**, **буду учителем**. With location/adverbs, instrumental is not used: **был дома**.

examples.translation_text: Tomorrow I will be at home?
examples.notes: Future with буду (location can omit instrumental).

grammar_points.usage_notes: Include a note that **стать** means 'to become' and is very common for changes of status; it typically takes instrumental for the new role/status.

grammar_points.title: Yes/no questions with ли after focused element
grammar_points.summary: Yes/no questions with ли after focused element
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Yes/no questions with ли after focused element.

**How to use it:** Use this structure to ask for specific information. Keep the rest of the sentence in neutral order unless you want to emphasize one part.

**Common pattern:** `WH + (subject) + verb + ...`

**Watch for:** intonation (especially in spoken Russian) and agreement when the WH-word changes like an adjective (**чей**, **который**).

examples.notes: ли after focused element (odd word order is possible).

grammar_points.title: Double negation structure in Russian
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Double negation structure in Russian.

Russian normally uses **double negation**: a negative word (никто/ничего/никогда/нигде…) appears together with **не** on the verb.

**Core patterns**
- `никто + не + verb` = nobody …
- `нет + (кого/чего)` = there is no / I don't have …

**Watch for:** negative pronouns decline by case, so the form changes depending on the role in the sentence.

grammar_points.title: Genitive for possession (noun + genitive)
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Genitive for possession (noun + genitive).

This point focuses on one **atomic** use of the **genitive** case that shows up constantly in A2 communication.

**How to use it**
- Learn the *meaning/function* first (why this case is used).
- Then learn the *form* on high‑frequency nouns/pronouns/adjectives that appear with it.

**Watch for**
- Prepositions often “select” a case (e.g., **после + Genitive**, **к + Dative**, **о + Prepositional**).
- Pronouns and adjectives must match the case too, not just the noun.

examples.translation_text: After the lesson I go home.

grammar_points.title: Personal pronoun declension: я
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Personal pronoun declension: я.

At A2, pronouns stop being “one form” and become a **mini‑declension system**. You need the correct pronoun form to:
- mark **case** (object vs possession vs location, etc.)
- keep speech natural and avoid repeating nouns

**How to learn it**
- Memorize the core table (nom/gen/dat/acc/inst/prep).
- Practice inside fixed frames: `у меня …`, `со мной …`, `обо мне …`, `к нему …`.

**Watch for:** **себя / свой** refer back to the subject (“oneself / one’s own”).

examples.example_text: Это моя книга, а это твоя.
examples.translation_text: This is my book, and this is yours.

grammar_points.title: Adjective declension: masculine singular across cases
grammar_points.summary: Adjective declension: masculine singular across cases
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Adjective declension: masculine singular across cases.

A2 requires describing and comparing more precisely. This point targets one **adjective/adverb mechanism** you can test directly (endings or comparative forms).

**Key idea:** adjectives change for **gender/number/case**, and adverbs often come from adjectives (`быстрый → быстро`).

**Watch for:** animate vs inanimate affects accusative adjective forms; comparatives can be regular (**-ее/-ей**) or irregular (**лучше**, **хуже**, etc.).

grammar_points.title: Hundreds formation
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Hundreds formation.

A2 learners need to talk about **dates, time, quantities, and years** beyond A1. Numerals also “pull” certain case forms from nouns.

**Use it for**
- schedules and appointments
- telling dates and years
- measuring time spans

**Watch for:** after many numerals, the **noun form changes** (genitive patterns), and some time expressions are idiomatic (e.g., **половина третьего**).

grammar_points.title: Imperfective vs perfective: core conceptual contrast
grammar_points.summary: Imperfective vs perfective: core conceptual contrast
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Imperfective vs perfective: core conceptual contrast.

Aspect is a core A2 upgrade: Russian verbs come in pairs that highlight **process/habit** (imperfective) vs **completed result** (perfective).

**Practical decision rule**
- imperfective: “what I was doing / usually do”
- perfective: “what I finished / happened once”

**Watch for:** time words like **уже** often push you toward perfective; negation contrasts can change meaning (`не делал` vs `не сделал`).

grammar_points.title: Conditional with бы + past tense
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Conditional with бы + past tense.

A2 conversation needs softer, more polite intent and basic hypotheticals. This point gives you a **reliable frame** for:
- polite requests (**бы**, **можно**)
- obligations (**должен**, **надо/нужно**)
- purpose (**чтобы**) and conditions (**если**)

**Watch for:** with **бы**, Russian typically uses the **past tense form** even though the meaning is “would/could”.

examples.translation_text: If there is time, I'll come.

grammar_points.title: идти vs ходить
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** идти vs ходить.

At A2 you start combining **motion verbs** with **prefixes** to specify direction and endpoints:
- arrival, departure, entry/exit, etc.

**How to learn it**
- treat each prefix as its own meaning unit
- pair a perfective and imperfective form (e.g., `прийти / приходить`)

**Watch for:** prefixes interact with aspect; perfective forms are common for “one completed trip.”

grammar_points.title: Subordinate clause with что
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Subordinate clause with что.

A2 learners begin chaining ideas into **multi‑clause sentences**:
- statements with **что**
- time/condition clauses (**когда**, **если**)
- relative clauses with **который**

**Core punctuation rule:** put a **comma** before the subordinate/relative clause in writing.

**Watch for:** **который** must agree and decline by the role it plays inside the clause.

examples.translation_text: I know that he's at home.
This is the person who helped me.

grammar_points.title: Impersonal weather and time expressions
grammar_points.explanation:
**What it does:** Impersonal weather and time expressions.

This point supports A2 communication by adding a specific structure you can practice directly.

**How to use it:** Learn it as a pattern first, then expand with new vocabulary.

**Watch for:** case agreement, verb endings, and word order in questions/negation.

examples.translation_text: It's hard for me to understand.
It's time for me to go.
